channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene: House Republicans resist pressure to oust lawmaker
item.description: Marjorie Taylor Greene's remarks were offensive but came before she was elected, a party leader says.

item.title: Myanmar coup: UN chief Guterres calls for failure of military takeover
item.description: The UN's secretary general calls the takeover "unacceptable" and pledges international pressure.

item.title: Covid: UK 'past this peak' but infections still 'alarmingly high'
item.description: Boris Johnson praises health workers' efforts in helping the UK pass 10 million first vaccinations.

item.title: Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick lies in honour at US Capitol
item.description: He died from injuries sustained while on duty during the Capitol riots on 6 January.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics chief Yoshiro Mori 'sorry' for sexism row
item.description: Yoshiro Mori, a former Japanese prime minister, said women "have difficulty" speaking concisely.

item.title: Golden Globes 2021: Three female directors make history in nominations
item.description: Three women are nominated for best director - the first time more than one has been shortlisted.

item.title: Morgan Wallen: US country star dropped by his record label over racial slur
item.description: Morgan Wallen's music has also been removed by hundreds of US radio stations over the scandal.

item.title: Covid: New Oxford vaccine 'ready by the autumn' to tackle mutations
item.description: An improved jab that will be more effective against variants can be made quickly, says Oxford-AstraZeneca.

item.title: Texas officials apologise after 'Chucky' missing child alert
item.description: Texas officials sent a test message naming the horror character as a suspect in a child abduction.

item.title: Draghi asked to form new Italian coalition government
item.description: The former European Central Bank chief is asked by the president to form a new coalition government.

item.title: Proud Boys: Canada labels far-right group a terrorist entity
item.description: The government notes the far-right group's role in the US Capitol riot in Washington last month.

item.title: Covid: Australian MPs clash in hallway over misinformation
item.description: In a hallway confrontation, Tanya Plibersek accuses opponent Craig Kelly of spreading misinformation.

item.title: Harry Dunn: Suspect Anne Sacoolas 'worked for US intelligence'
item.description: The US court hears Anne Sacoolas feared she would not get a fair trial if she returned to the UK.

item.title: Mariah Carey sued by sister Alison over 'vindictive' book
item.description: The US singer's older sibling wants $1.2m for distress caused by comments in her recent memoir.

item.title: Brits snap up Australian wine that didn't go to China
item.description: The UK is now the top destination for Australian wine as it looks to overcome crippling Chinese taxes.

item.title: Australian Open stars isolate after hotel Covid case
item.description: Up to 600 Australian Open players, officials and support staff will go into isolation - until they test negative - after a coronavirus case at a Melbourne hotel.

item.title: So what is Jeff Bezos going to do now?
item.description: After stepping down as CEO of Amazon, Bezos says he will focus on his 'other passions'.

item.title: South Korea's 'hidden' migrant workers
item.description: Migrant farm workers, many from South East Asian countries, are living in squalid conditions just outside Seoul, one of Asia's wealthiest capitals.

item.title: Sinovac and Sinopharm - what do we know about the Chinese vaccines?
item.description: China has 16 vaccines in development, but those from Sinovac and Sinopharm are the front-runners.

item.title: The YouTuber and the school row over masturbation
item.description: What should teenage girls be taught about sex and when?

item.title: Influencers told not to use 'misleading' beauty filters
item.description: The Advertising Standards Authority ruling applies to brands and influencers on social media.

item.title: Haunting images of America's painful past
item.description: Rich Frishman has travelled the United States, documenting the vestiges of racial oppression that are all around us.

item.title: Solar energy empowers young women in Yemen
item.description: Ten women in Yemen’s Abs district have built and now run a solar microgrid.

item.title: Ancient mummies with golden tongues unearthed in Egypt
item.description: It is thought the dead were given the tongues 2,000 years ago so they could speak in the afterlife.

item.title: GameStop: Real Wolf of Wall Street warns 'you could lose it all'
item.description: Jordan Belfort says amateurs should "take their chips off the table" as shares in the retailer tumble.

item.title: Covid-19: Fact-checking Macron's claim about the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine
item.description: France is one of a number of EU countries which is not recommending the jab for those over 65.

item.title: Coronavirus: German medics fly in to aid Portugal's hospital emergency
item.description: Almost a year after Italy sought help because of its virus emergency, Portugal welcomes German aid.

item.title: Why jailing Navalny may mean more problems for Putin
item.description: The Kremlin's tough tactics could backfire, with the opposition leader's jail term fuelling protests.

item.title: Is high-speed rail travel on a track to nowhere?
item.description: The recently scrapped Singapore-Kuala Lumpur train link isn't the only such project to struggle.

item.title: China promotes education drive to make boys more 'manly'
item.description: The education ministry comes under criticism for moves to "prevent the feminisation" of young boys.

item.title: Racial Impostor Syndrome: When you're made to feel like a fake
item.description: New York school student Arden Yum says ethnic minority children may not identify with the racial identity they were born with.

item.title: 'Their goal is to destroy everyone': Uighur camp detainees allege systematic rape
item.description: In new testimony, former detainees of China's detention camps describe systematic rape and torture.

item.title: 'Courage, quality, togetherness' - Brighton win leaves Liverpool seven points off top
item.description: Brighton move 10 points clear of the relegation zone with a surprise victory, as Liverpool's recent struggles at Anfield continue.

item.title: Leaders Man City beat Burnley for 13th successive win
item.description: Manchester City beat Burnley to restore a three-point advantage at the top of the Premier League and extend their winning streak to 13 games.

item.title: Injured Crawley may miss England's first Test against India
item.description: England's Zak Crawley may miss the first Test against India in Chennai after injuring his wrist in training.

item.title: Wales suspend Adams over Covid breach
item.description: Wing Josh Adams is released by Wales after being suspended for the first two matches of the Six Nations following a breach of Covid-19 protocols.

item.title: Liverpool not fresh mentally or physically - Klopp
item.description: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp says his side were "not fresh enough, mentally and physically" as Brighton consigned them to a second straight home defeat.

item.title: Lingard debut double in West Ham win over Villa
item.description: David Moyes says Jesse Lingard can make England's Euros squad after he scores twice on his West Ham debut.

item.title: Leicester overcome Fulham to strengthen top-four push
item.description: Leicester strengthen their position in the Premier League's top four with victory over Fulham, whose survival hopes suffer a further blow at Craven Cottage.

item.title: Myanmar coup: What is happening and why?
item.description: Myanmar hit headlines around the world on Monday when its military seized control.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Min Aung Hlaing, the general who seized power
item.description: Min Aung Hlaing rose through the ranks of the army to become commander-in-chief before seizing power.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Fitness instructor unwittingly films video as takeover unfolds
item.description: Recording her dance routine, Khing Hnin Wai had no idea she was filming a military takeover.

item.title: 'I was five when they snatched my father'
item.description: The coup has sent a chill through many in the country who grew up under decades of military rule.

item.title: Myanmar coup: How the military disrupted the internet
item.description: As the military took power, internet access was restricted in many parts of the country, but how was it done?
